results:
Based on my search results, I can provide you with information about "One Hundred Years of Solitude" and its presence in popular culture across various media:

## Film and Television Adaptations

Netflix announced a TV adaptation of the book in March 2019, with Netflix commemorating the fortieth anniversary of García Márquez's Nobel Prize announcement with an exclusive preview in October 2022, and releasing the official teaser on the tenth anniversary of García Márquez's death, revealing the series will run for sixteen episodes. The eight-part series was filmed in Colombia, in Spanish, with an entirely local cast, and the first season is available on Netflix, with critics praising it as "nothing short of magical".

Japanese filmmaker Shūji Terayama created unauthorized adaptations with his play "One Hundred Years of Solitude" and his film "Farewell to the Ark," transplanting the story into Japanese culture and history.

## Music References and Inspirations

The novel has inspired numerous musical works across different genres and countries:

### International Musicians
Italian band Modena City Ramblers based most of their 1997 album "Terra e Libertà" on One Hundred Years of Solitude, including tracks "Macondo Express," "Il ballo di Aureliano," "Remedios la bella" and "Cent'anni di solitudine".

American guitarist Bill Frisell included a song titled "Remedios the Beauty" on his 1988 album "Lookout for Hope", and American composer Roger Reynolds's 1979 multimedia work "Voicespace: Eclipse" uses text from the novel.

Radiohead's song was possibly inspired by One Hundred Years of Solitude, with lyrics about industrialization in a small town.

### Latin American Musicians
Colombian artists have created tributes including Rodolfo Aicardi's "Me Voy Pa' Macondo" and Rafael Orozco's vallenato "Cien años de Macondo," which mentions yellow butterflies, golden fish, and Mauricio Babilonia.

Mexican singer Oscar Chavez based a song on Macondo from the novel, which "became a tropical hit and is now heavily covered by mariachis".

Venezuelan musician Juan Vicente Torrealba wrote a merengue called "Macondo".

## BookTok and Social Media Presence

On TikTok, BookTok creators discuss the novel with hashtags like #booktok #onehundredyearsofsolitude, with some noting the "catchy" opening line. Some BookTok users express mixed reactions, with one creator asking "Am i missing something?" after 50 pages, seeking advice on whether to continue reading.

Other TikTok users praise the book, with one stating "I loved One Hundred Years of Solitude" while acknowledging the need to focus while reading, and another describing "every sentence of this book was magical".

## Other Cultural References

The magical village of Macondo inspired a World of Warcraft mission called "Ever so Lonely," which incorporates several elements from the book.

A comic book titled "Memories of a Magical Life" was created about García Márquez's life, featuring yellow as the dominant color and exploring the creation of One Hundred Years of Solitude.

The novel's enduring influence across multiple forms of media demonstrates its continued relevance in contemporary popular culture, from streaming adaptations to social media discussions and musical tributes spanning multiple decades and countries.
